timeline.message: initial processing around the broken invariant

timeline.bodyText: moved these around and made some static; the diff renders weirdly here
timeline.author: Jolyon-S
Jolyon-S

timeline.message: Merge branch 'lw-max-size-retention' of github.com:palantir/atlasdb into lw-max-size-retention
add extra test for commit update too
reorder a whole load of things to fix some bugs
resolve yet another sneaky edge case

timeline.bodyText: Feels impossible? Or if you think it's possible, this should really live in the LockWatchEvents?
timeline.author: jkozlowski

replies.bodyText: Should be impossible, I just don't like doing Optional.get() blindly. I've moved to LockWatchEvents.
replies.author: Jolyon-S

timeline.bodyText:
I have a pretty strong opinion that your datastructures should not let themselves be instantiated in a way that makes them inconsistent. I think there's a pretty strong assumption everywhere that startTsToSequence should be contained within LockWatchEvents.
So I suggest moving the validation you have in LockWatchEventCacheImpl#getUpdateForTransactions to here.
timeline.author: jkozlowski

replies.bodyText: Ok, I re-read the changes you actually added and it seems like there's obviously the case when the client is up-to-date, therefore the update is empty. I would actually suggest that we add the "latestVersion" field to both TransactionsLockWatchUpdate and ClientLogEvents, and basically do this validation in the datastructures. What do you think?
replies.author: jkozlowski

replies.bodyText: (somewhat - I didn't add latestVersion to TLWU).
replies.author: Jolyon-S

timeline.bodyText: While we're here, I missed this in one of the original reviews: this should not be called #map: map traditionally is a functor method, that transforms a value of some type T, but the T stays the same in the transformation. I would suggest something like #toTransactionsLockWatchUpdate or something else, but map is pretty misleading.
timeline.author: jkozlowski

timeline.bodyText: Not convinced on this comment. Just say this should be the same and provide a link to the timelock class.
timeline.author: jkozlowski
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -53,12 +50,18 @@
  * in concurrency issues and inconsistency in the cache state.
  */
 public final class LockWatchEventCacheImpl implements LockWatchEventCache {
+    /**
+     * This value should be at least as large as the max size in LockEventLogImpl. If it is smaller, it is possible that

replies.bodyText: I'll reference the timelock class informally, but you can't link it here since this package does not know about it (I'd already tried this before).
replies.author: Jolyon-S

timeline.bodyText: Same here: I feel like the validation again should be done in the CommitUpdate.
timeline.author: jkozlowski

timeline.bodyText:
I have a cute one:
timestampMapping().values().stream().mapToLong(
                LockWatchVersion::version).summaryStatistics()

should get you sorted?
timeline.author: jkozlowski

replies.bodyText: That is a cute one. Nice!
replies.author: Jolyon-S

timeline.bodyText: You're doing the empty check twice, perhaps should be a @Value.Check.
timeline.author: jkozlowski

replies.bodyText: I'll extract the empty check out, but I really don't like doing unchecked Optional.get() calls!
replies.author: Jolyon-S

replies.bodyText: Actually, using .distinct makes this unnecessary anyway. Nice!
replies.author: Jolyon-S

timeline.bodyText: I wonder if using #distinct and collecting and checking only single value is fine? You don't expect this ever fire, it's a bug, so shouldn't collect a huge amount of values.
timeline.author: jkozlowski

replies.bodyText: aaactually, are we sure this is disallowed by atlas? I know we check for this in atlasdb-proxy and discard, but I think because Atlas can end up running multiple queries for a particular batch, this is actually possible?
replies.author: jkozlowski

replies.bodyText:
Hmm, you maybe right, I think we won't even get to this point when they're different, because the cache itself will clear the values? So the lookup for lock watch versions will fail before this.
Nice addition!
replies.author: jkozlowski

replies.bodyText:
In any case, we don't want to return multiple leaders, because it will just cause those transactions to conflict further down the line anyway - so at best, this would be a retryable exception.
However, as you note, I don't think we should ever hit this, as a new leader will wipe all previous state, including current timestamp mappings (so we won't be able to get it from the cache - if timestamp versions are not present because of this kind of thing, we retry anyway).
replies.author: Jolyon-S

timeline.bodyText: Would it be much of change in tests to change VersionedEventStore#putAll to take LockWatchEvents?
timeline.author: jkozlowski

timeline.bodyText: This feels like more of a test of LockWatchEvents? I'd remove it, since you're checking the whole set of events in the line above.
timeline.author: jkozlowski

replies.bodyText: That's true - I was just porting it over from the previous, but actually you're right in that it is redundant.
replies.author: Jolyon-S

timeline.bodyText: Perhaps you want eventCache = createEventCache(5); here, since most tests don't want any retention to happen?
timeline.author: jkozlowski

timeline.bodyText: I'm assuming this is because of no-compression and this will change in next PR.
timeline.author: jkozlowski

replies.bodyText:
No compression
Retention change (i.e. keeps some values around).
replies.author: Jolyon-S

timeline.bodyText: I'm assuming you just wanted to make this test do a bit more by adding the extra timestamp to lookup?
timeline.author: jkozlowski

timeline.bodyText: Hmm, I feel like I'd rather keep it as an assertion, and maybe rename the test? And if you add the "latestVersion" to TransactionUpdate that can tighten this test as well?
timeline.author: jkozlowski

replies.bodyText:
I've actually changed the test:

before, it was testing that a client that is on the exact same version as the cache will not throw
now, it's testing that a client that is on the same version as the transaction (but not the cache) will not throw.

It'd probably be best here if I make sure we have both of those tests.
replies.author: Jolyon-S

timeline.message: Move version range present check to lock watch events
rename method from map to toTransactionsLockWatchUpdate
